30 Years of Research and Development around Coq Gérard Huet INRIA Paris Rocquencourt, France Gerard.Huet&#169;inria.fr 
The Coq Proof Assistant is an interactive software system based on higher-order type theory, designed 
and implemented by a team of French researchers as a continuous effort over the last 30 years. It implements 
a logical framework, called the Calculus of Induc­tive Constructions, endowed with notational facilities 
and a mod­ular structure, allowing its use as a high-level language .t for the development of compositional 
mathematical components. Explicit potential proof structures are built by execution of ML tactics and 
tacticals, along a choice of proof schemes combinators. This al­lows a wide spectrum of inference granularity, 
from step-by-step inference, to full decision procedures and re.ection principles. The validity of such 
a potential proof is veri.ed by an independent core proof checker, whose meta-theory has been itself 
formally justi.ed. Coq proofs may be seen as programs in a high-level func­tional notation, decorated 
by correctness assertions, and translators into existing programming languages such as OCaml and Haskell 
are available. Conversely, specialized subsystems allow the devel­opment of algorithms with logical assertions,

is in use by a large community of users. Some notable successes have been achieved, in formalized mathematics 
(the 4 color theorem, the odd order theorem in group theory), as well as in software certi.cation (a 
Java Card processing environ­ment, the CompCert certi.ed C compiling project). The talk will have two 
parts. First, Gérard Huet will evoke the genesis of Coq, its roots in early type theory, through the 
in.u­ence of Per Martin-Löf s dependent type theory, Jean-Yves Gi­rard s polymorphic .-calculi F and 
F., Nicolaas de Bruijn s Au­tomath languages and type-checkers, and the ML-LCF-Hope effort of Robin Milner 
and colleagues at the University of Edinburgh. He will discuss the rationale behind a few design decisions, 
and brie.y evoke the historical contributors in the 80s and 90 s. Hugo Herbe­lin will then address a 
couple of contemporary issues related to the logical status of equality, the proof methods, the high-level 
speci.­cation language, the user interfaces.
title: 30 years of research and development around Coq
